title: Squirrel Whistle Calls (Two Versions) Updated to Mk 2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE part of the squirrel distress whistle calls were just too thin for many printing methods. So I've updated it and they should print better now. I also added a loop for attaching a string on the v1 model.

Ok, so I got into squirrel hunting. They don't taste too bad actually. But they are illusive little buggers! I saw the squirrel distress whistle calls online and attempted to replicate them just from pictures, and failed epically. So I bought the two most prevalent squirrel distress whistles on the market and found out what I was doing wrong. I remodeled both and tested them and they tested perfectly!

Even if you aren't hunting them, these little whistles are still fun to just mess with the little guys. They would make for a cool Cub Scout, Weebleos, and Boy Scout projects

The first thing I found out (once I had the commercial ones on hand) is that the hole in the middle needs to be about 5mm, any smaller and you don't get good results, any bigger and it's kind of the same. You also need a little chamber in the middle. The size of the chamber in the middle of the two pieces has to be small as well, otherwise you get a deeper sound if you make that chamber too big. I did in my initial attempts. I may play around with making the diameter of the v1 a smidge smaller at some point in the future, but for now I'm quite happy with my results.

So the bigger one is my favorite (v1). It's close (and by close I mean almost perfectly exactly close) to the Mr. Squirrel Call, which works wonderfully. And by that I mean the commercial one and the one that I modeled here. This one (that I printed in ABS on a zortrax with fine detail) sounds every bit as good (IMHO). This is my 3rd of 4th revision, but I'm confident it is perfected now.

The smaller one is modeled after the sound making portion of the Lohman Mr. B's Distress Squirrel Whistle. Which actually has a resonance tube as part of it. I modeled the sound tube holder for it as well, but the sound maker works fine without it. This one sounds pretty spot on as well. If you print the tube you don't have to glue the two pieces of the sound maker together, as the tube will hold both pieces together. I have now printed the tubes (I designed two of them), and the sound makers fit perfectly into them, so I'm considering this to be a fully successful project. The tube makes the call a bit louder, and directional.

I printed two of either of the v1 or v2, out of ABS on a Zortrax printer. Then I glued the two pieces together with acetone. So what I did was just hold the two pieces together in my hand. Then I soaked a cotton swap in acetone, then wiped the cotton swap with acetone along the seam of the two pieces. The acetone will seep into the crack and fuse the two pieces together, permanently. Simple.

I recommend printing on a printer that has a really high resolution like a zortrax or an SLA printer, because the parts are small and have fine detail. Printing two of either of the sound maker pieces should only run you about 30-45 minutes or so. I have not printed these on a PrintRbot or Makerbot yet. So if you do, please take a picture of it and post it here, I'm sure everyone will be interested in how they turn out. I know I would be. Printing these in Flexible material would be interesting, but I doubt the fine detail would come out smoothly enough. PLA would probably work, but it's too brittle for me.

I have to admit, I've grown lazy and I've started using TinkerCAD almost all the time. I can model things faster and easier than any other CAD design package on the market. I've used Inventor, Fusion 360, and FreeCAD. But none of them are as easy to use for designing as TinkerCAD. With the new design interface you can put bevels on your geometric primitives, which I do all the time now.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/a4TQcHqtnSS

comments.text:
IT WORKS !! -
Putting the tube call together: The very first tube call has three parts, the two flat lip "deep dish" circles and then the tube. The far left image shows how the tube call circles fits together, they are put in on top of each other in the tube. (End over end )The two "deep dish" circles go on top of each other with the flat lip part facing down and then the second flat lip circle is put facing down as well on top it. I used a few dabs of white school glue on mine to hold it in place on the tube.

remixed_from.author: gpvillamil
remixed_from.title: Customizable drawer box with hex pattern sides

description.text:
Based in "Parts Tray Drawer" by FatalError3141 [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398548], and "Customizable drawer box with hex pattern sides" by gpvillamil [http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:421886], this is my first attempt with customizable drawers box.
Designed with printing speed in mind, it's written in OpenSCAD and it's main goal is to be fully parametric so you can define separately the main size of the box, the wall thickness (in case you want to print it with only 1 perimeter to improve speed), the bottom thickness and the tolerance between parts.
It includes 4 different types of drawer in the same .scad file, with 1 to 4 divisions that dinamically adapt to main box size.
It's designed to be printed without supports. Can be printed without rafts.

With thickness parameter defined in 0.6mm it can be printed in about 1 hour and 57 minutes (Cura parameters: layer=0.3mm, Shell=0.4mm, Bottom thickness=1mm, Fill=10%, Speed=65mm/s)

Update [20 jan]:
I printed the drawer box today, 1 shell only. I included photo of the model. It took 1hr and 36 min using these settings in Cura:

  • nozzle = 0.4mm
  • resolution = 0.3mm
  • shell = 0.4mm
  • bottom/top thickness = 1mm
  • infill = 0
  • speed = 85mm/s

description.text:
These brackets are to complement the mount made by Ryan Zellars in his MPCNC kit for the 25mm pipe EU version. It was designed by measuring the Mckeller 600w mckm28 router and importing the mount plate from the MPCNC as a mesh into F360. There are three parts, the top two can be printed twice to improve on rigidity.

I would say use at your own risk, i have uploaded this on request from another user on the vicious one facebook group. It is yet to be fully tested in operation, however it has been test fit to the plate and the router.

EDIT The top rear bracket cracked on me the other day, so I may have to modify this. I think the Issue may be that Mckeller router is not really a circular cylindrical piece which means that the four rounded corners create points of high pressure.

comments.author: UltimateRoar

comments.text: Amazing how good these are designed. I printed one out, and while the second one was printing I went to a SkateBoard shop at the mall which had the bearing very cheap. (They are the same bearings used on most all skateboards.) I put them on last night. The nuts were too tight to push in the little slots (But I like the idea of them being tight,) so I heated up a flat head screw driver and pushed it again the inside of the slot a couple times until the nut fit better, but was still tight so it stayed in place. Every one of these printers should come with these standard. They make the Z Axis rock solid. Before installing,,, the top of the Z-Axis could be moved almost an inch in all directions which moved the print head a lot. I installed these and 4 Eccentric spacers from Amazon on the back 2 wheels of the Z-Axis and the head is now rock solid. Thank you for the great design. A picture of mine can be seen at.. http://www.dignet.us/TronXYZsup.JPG
comments.author: RBDiggins

comments.text: Thanks for this comment! It really gave me some boost to think about uploading my other upgrades :) The thing with the tightness of holes is, I think it is always gonna be a problem to come up with perfect fits, because almost everyone's printer (especially reprap) will have slightly different tolerances and I made it for my printer to be able to print it as I needed. But I am glad you made it work.. And I am also glad you like it and that it works for you.
comments.author: RBDiggins

comments.text: The tightness of the holes was not a problem at all. I would rather have them tight than where the nuts fall out like they do on a lot of projects here.   I only mentioned it to give someone else the idea of heating up a very small flat head screw driver to make small adjustments in the hex nut slot.    I think your design should be listed as the #1 mod for improving print quality.   All anyone has to do is move the top of their Z-Screws and watch how far the head moves.  It quickly illustrates how much you mod will stabilize the head.   Can't give you enough kudos for such a great easy to implement design.  Thanks Again.

print_settings.Notes:: There is a big overhang at the start of the print.  My printer seemed to handle it fine w/o support.  Feel free to add support for easier overhang print, just remember to only have bed supports.

description.text:
UPDATE (06.05.17) If the duct doesn't say in place you could try http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297996 . It fixes it to one of the fan screws.
Added step file for easier modification.

UPDATE (18.04.17) It has been noticed that in some cases air stream directed downwards will bounce off the bed and will come up towards the nozzle. In order compensate use 'regular fan speed at height' Cura option. Set it to something like 50 mm, so the fan speed will ramp up as the nozzle moves farther away from the bed. Leave your experiences int he comments.

UPDATE (10.04.17) An updated model (version 4) that clears the heater block is uploaded. There is now a cutout that should accommodate the corners of the heater block, in addition, I moved the whole structure 1mm down, it still still hangs ~2mm above the tip of the hotend nozzle, shouldn't get in contact with the print.

This is yet another fan duct for a Anet printers. This is inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620630 but not quite a remix. After I've i finalized the idea i discovered quite many similar things and concepts.

Why is mine better?

  • The biggest advantage is the targeted air flow, the whole structure hangs ~2 mm above the tip of the extruder nozzle but the air flow has a 'focal point' ~2mm below it. So rather then splashing cold air all over the hotend, the air flows to extruded plastic and the part below. This means that your hotend heater is not working against your cooling fan, better hotend temperature control and less current consumption (a win-win)
  • Internal surfaces are optimized for airflow and smaller 'internal resistance', you can probably run your fan at 50% without loss of cooling efficiency
  • The cross section of the doughnut is much bigger then cross section of the air outlet, the air pressure is roughly similar in all points of the doughnut. This means that airflow from all outlets is also similar. The extruded plastic is cooled evenly from all sides.
  • There are 4 guides that show the direction of the airflow
  • It looks good (even if i say so myself)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

There is a big overhang at the start of the print. My printer seemed to handle it fine w/o support. Feel free to add support for easier overhang print, just remember to only have bed supports.

This was something of a design challenge as the intake from the fan is off center for the doughnut, designing a smooth assymetrical solid took some time, hopefully i've learned something about modeling in the process

comments.text:
Something is really wrong then, i don't think it would be related to the fan duct.
How are you measuring the change? The controller tries to keep the hotend temperature constant, so if it gets cooled by incorrect airflow, the controller will run more power to the heater to try to compensate, so the temperature will be same, but the heater will do more work.

comments.text:
Do tell how it plays out for you. I've been using mine for a bunch of prints now, and i have no problems at all with nozzle temperature. Other people have reported problems with geometry, but nothing so serious as 30C difference. The printer electronics should be capable of pumping more current through the heater, it should go up to 250 at least for the ABS.
One thing you could try if the problem persists is to lower fan speed, i think i saw this option in Cura, set it to 50% and see what effect does this have.
comments.author: Robofriven

comments.text: Alright, reprinted it and here is what I have.  With stock nozzle I get no drops at all, no matter what. In a 16C basement (so it's definitely blowing cold air at it) with a set point of 200C I am getting drops down to 179.8 at .2mm off the bed.  At 1.2mm I am getting 180.2C, 2.2mm gives 188.7C, and at 3.2mm it bounces back to 200 after a little while.
comments.author: anverx

comments.text:
You are correct, when nozzle is fairly close to the bed, a stock blower is better since that sends the air one way horizontally, while this duct tries to push the air down, and when it finds no escape downwards it goes every which way including up, also the duct itself blocks the escaping air from going sideways. This effect can generally be mitigated by lowering fan speed for first few mm of the print, (i wonder if there is an option for that in the slicer). While moving up it becomes more efficient then the stock. The aerodynamics of this are slightly more complicated then i expected ;)
I still wonder why is the effect so much more pronounced in your machine. I have temperature graphs from octaprint and they do wobble about by couple of degrees but not more than that and in no systematic fashion.
comments.author: Robofriven

comments.text: Playing around with several settings I got something that works close enough and that is to go into expert mode in Cura and change the "Fan full on at height" to 5mm.  That will progressively speed the fan up so that it doesn't reach full speed until 5mm.  Other than that you can go into the gcode and change the fan speed manually if you wanted, but that seems a little cumbersome.

comments.text:
So with. what material did you print it,
Just by looking at it, this seems to be a very efficient fan duct, but it is very close to the hot end.
What will happen if you print an object without cooling?
comments.author: Tavero

comments.text:
This is printed with PLA.
Depending on the shape of your heater block the duct might be in the way. My development version of the duct actually got in contact with the corner of the heater block, but nothing bad happened, it got slightly deformed, didn't melt away, didn't start a fire, didn't change the airflow. The last revision that i'm using all the time, fits a tiny bit better and doesn't come in contact with the heater block. In any case i recommend coating the heater block with ceramic wool or whichever thermal insulator is available to you.
comments.author: Tavero

comments.text: Nice design with a new approach for the airflow focal point. I do have some questions on your assumptions. Note that the used fans are not capable of increasing the pressure (substantially, as they are not compressors), this is a widespread mistake (similar as PC fans; decreasing the flow passage just stalls the fans so that the actual flow decreases and the flow speed does not increase). The original fan duct is a perfect example of how not to design a fan duct (airflow is close to nothing). These fans merely displace airflow. From an aerodynamic point of view you should decrease the area of your torus (main channel) with the amount of area the torus ejects (also be sure the exit area is not larger than the initial area just after the fan). In simple words, when you loose airflow by ejection, you should decrease the area of the main channel accordingly. If you don't, the left airflow has the same main channel passage to flow through and decreases in speed. This means that the furthest away from the fan the speed is lowest (uneven flow distribution). You see this problem with all the fans going around Thingiverse.
comments.author: 0scar

comments.text: I agree that the fan is not a compressor, but it acts like one at low RPM, the higher the RPM the more flow, up to a point.
comments.author: 0scar

comments.text: Looks good! It's amazing how many fan ducts are available but this one does look promising.

author: Jace1969

title: Syringe (5ml) adapter for Generic Ibuprofen or paracetamol bottle

description.text: Brand name ibuprofen has a syringe adapter for a proprietary syringe, but 5ml (or smaller/larger) are cheaper, more available and can be used again and again for other bottles. These adapters create a seal with the appropriate hole for the syringe to draw the liquid up without mess or fuss. Simply measure the inner diameter of your bottle with a caliper and rework the file for your own use.

title: CTC Endstop Z-Achse Schlitten Aufnahme Knopf Verstellbar Adjustment(Überarbeitet)

description.text:
Hallo jungs....

Der Holger hier bei Thingi hat schon ein echt tolles Teil erstellt.
http://www.thingiverse.com/Beware/designs

Allerdings fast unbrauchbar , da der Wunsch nach einer Welle die durch 2 stifte fixiert wird einfach nicht funktioniert hat..
Des weiteren fehlte die Möglichkeit die hintere Platte (schlitten) an der Rückwand des CTC zu befestigen.
Beide Dinge habe ich etwas anders gestaltet.
Ich moechte hier nicht fremde Lorbeeren einheimsen und daher biete ich den endstop schlitten auch nur an mit dem Verweis das der Holger (The Brain) von dem ganzen ist ;)....

Ihr benötigt zusaätzlich noch:

1 x M3 Gewindestang ca. 90mm Lang
4 x M3 Unterlegscheiben
4 x M3 Selbstsichernde Muttern
2 x M3 x 15 Inbus Schrauben mit Zylinderkopf
3 x M3 4 Kant Muttern
Bevor ihr ihn an der Rückwand Montieren möchtet , sollte alles schon fertig Montiert sein sonst wirds mehr Fummelei als Spass ;)

Position und Fertiger Verstellbarer Endstop Schalter ist auf dem Bild gut zu erkennen.

Nun viel Spass beim Drucken..

title: Extensions for Terraforming Mars Game
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you play the board game Terraforming Mars and want to print some 3D Tiles there is an excellent collection here:

https://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/142444/3d-printable-stl-terrain-pieces

What I have done is added some of my own twists. This includes two new Sperrgebiet (Exclusion Area) tiles and two Ocean tiles. I had problems printing in the first case and wanted something that would print with less extruder movements in the second case. There is also a hat that you can print for the top of a dome if you should choose to print the Domed City model.

The other thing included here is a case for a collection of printed tiles. There should be room in the case for 25 greenery tiles and 15 city tiles in addition to the 9 ocean and 7 special tiles that make up the collection. Note that I have only printed and painted 22 and 12 of the greenery and city tiles.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200microns

Notes:

The bars version of the exclusion area should print on any machine that can do a decent bridge. The chainlink version may require you to play a little with extrusion width.

The tiles case may not work well in PLA as it was designed for a copolymer filament that allows the lid to flex so it fits over the pegs that secure it to the case. It will probably be ok printed in PET(-G) or even ABS. I used Colorfabb NGEN.

author: Xantraa

title: Cable guide for Original Prusa MK2

description.text:
Just a simple clip to hold up the extruder cables as mine were hanging onto the bed. Didn't want to print the cable chains just yet. I only made a hole for the USB but its easily removed if needed without any tools.

I used the default MK2 profile to print.

UPDATE
I do not use this clip anymore, as it was a quick fix.

I had to rebuild my extruder because the pinda probe broke off and I was not able to glue it back on properly. After twisting the filament in the cable bundle upwards and tie wrapping the cable bundle better it no longer drags on my printer bed.
You might want to do the same, there are enough tie wraps supplied to try again.

description.text:
created to dampen vibrations caused by Y axis movement. Helps stiffen the frame significantly. I put one one each on the front over the 8mm threaded rods, and one in each back corner. screwed directly to my table, or you could use plywood underneath. Rear mount has a cutout for cables to run through.

Small update: for those of you unsure on whether this will help, I have been using them now for 3 weeks and there is an insane difference between prints before and after. my prints hardly have any wobble or shift in them whatsoever now.

Edit: modified rear bracket to have a looser tolerance. It should fit snug now on the rear acrylic.

Edit 2: Uploaded a J-hook bracket for more mounting options

description.text: These dividers are designed for a Plano 2373130 case which helps keep your Catan sets organized. This fits into a backpack nicely and prevents all the pieces from getting mixed up. The following 4th edition sets all fit into this case: Catan base game, 6 player extension, seafarers expansion, seafarers extension. There is also room for one of MaxGjr's card holders. title: Revised Mounting Bracket for 3 x 3.5-Inch Drives in 2 x 5.25-Inch Drive Bays

description.text: This is a derivative of Neufeld's "Mounting Bracket for Three 3.5-Inch Drives in Two 5.25-Inch Drive Bays" and features clearance slots for the metal support tabs present in most desktop tower mounting bays that normally aid in drive alignment during installation. Without these clearance slots, it is not possible to install neufeld's original mounting brackets as the drive support tabs inhibit the brackets from spanning the entire bay.

• Print brackets
  • Mount hardrives in brackets
  • Install hardrives inside of computer bay
  • Begin hoarding all the data on the internets!

title: HTC Vive controller wall mount and charging station

description.text:
This is a wall mount for an HTC Vive wand. It can also optionally be used a a charging dock at the same time.

It was inspired by the existing wall mount http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1527199 which is also a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1443154 like this one. In both cases I found the original models a bit too clunky for my taste so I wanted to slim it down somewhat. Unfortunately the wall mount didn't come with any designer files so I used the original stand and re-created the wall mount.

It still uses the same plugin parts for the different kinds of Micro USB connectors as the others though (see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1443154 for those).

This object can be used as part of my All-In-One HTC Vive Mount HMD + Controllers + charging mounting solution where you'll need only 3 screws to fasten the entire thing to the wall instead of the 6 needed if you mount every piece separately.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed perfectly in PLA using Prusa's default NORMAL settings (with ZHop).

Printer model: Prusa MK2 (but that doesn't appear in the list)

The back plate has two holes for fixing the mount to a wall.

If used as part of my All-In-One HTC Vive Mount HMD + Controllers + charging mounting solution then you only need to use the top hole, otherwise you need to use both holes.

I thought it'd be more difficult to print that way though?
comments.author: quintesse

comments.text: No the way you did it should be the best way I think. But I'm trying to think why the bottom legs would snap off. Unless the nozzle is somehow exerting a lot of downward force on the print. Does it seem like the nozzle is dragging much through the upper layers?
comments.author: JoeyLYCAN

comments.text:
It doesn't seem like it's dragging at all. But I know even a slight hair of drag can cause an issue I'm sure. If that's what is doing it what would you recommend?
I'll try watching it very closely around the 70%+ mark next print.
I've already calibrated my esteps so over and under Extrusion shouldn't be an issue.
comments.author: quintesse

comments.text:
Ah another thing that comes to mind is that perhaps your layers are not sticking together enough. When you say it snaps of does it does so cleanly between layers? If so at what temperature are you printing? WIth what material?
You might see if you have this problem with other objects you printed: is it easy to pull thin objects apart? (It should be very difficult)
Or do some lines at the top or bottom come off easily if you scratch them with your nails?
If so you might experiment with higher temperatures.
Btw, I'm no 3d printer expert either so my advice might be completely off!
comments.author: JoeyLYCAN

comments.text: Well thanks for all the advice! I'm printing with PLA and Yes, it does snap cleanly, I haven't noticed anything easy to pull apart or scratch away with nails. I'll definitely Try adjusting the temperature a little higher, i'll bump it up maybe 210 from 200 and see how that goes! again thanks!

description.text:
I liked the original from which I remixed this Pi case from, but I wanted one with the Pi logo... also added feet that can be printed separately so its easier to print. I do believe the size should be right but you can always scale as needed before printing.  spaceclaim files are included as you can edit as needed or can use the solid works files that are in the original thing.  
enjoy.  
(oh printed in PLA, the opaque white I have prints very differently then my translucent colours I have as you can see it prints much worse and needed rafting the translucent prints right on kapton no problem)  
Item was rendered in KeyShot 4

print the outer shell flat side down. and the top shell same. upside down so that the flat side is down. print the side shell with supports and raft if you like. The white wasnt sticking well to the Kapton i could have layed some masking tape but didnt feel like re-leveling the platform. with the aluminum arms and glass platform i hardly have to re-level it. the feet you have two to choose from. Everything was printed at .15mm the feet i printed at .1mm took about 2h to print everything. HBP was set to 65 print head was set to 219. i let about three layers get built up then turned on a large fan to allow to cool everthing quickly and prevent warping the pla.

comments.text: the blue is translucent blue pla.the machine is a china duplicator 4 modded with bc technologies aluminum arms and glass hbp the pla was printed at 219 [email protected] 65. moving at 100mm/s no finishing needes as its printed directly on glass covered in kapton tape.if you print this on maskint tape then sand on 1000g paper and polish with compound.

description.text:

Adding the Roof

description.text: I made this because I got tired of using another cheapo stabilizer I cobbled together. It used 4 standard skate bearings, some 5/16" all thread, nuts, and fender washers. I designed everything from scratch with the exception of the camera mount. I based that off of one that I downloaded from Trimble's 3D warehouse, and modified it to accept a 1/2" nut in the base.

Assembly Notes

Everyting should be friction fit. I had trouble with my tolerances being too large initially especially with the pins on the yoke and handle. If your pins don't fit, you can try editing them in Sketchup, or just scaling them in your slicer of choice. If you look at my picture, assembly should be pretty straightforward. I designed this to work with my GoPro Hero 3, but it should work with any size small camera, presuming you weight it properly. Weighting it properly is essential to getting a smooth shot. If you don't add enough weight, you'll end up with a camera that won't stay upright, too much, and you'll have a pendulum with a handle.

A length of 5/16" all thread
8 nuts to screw onto your all thread
A package of fender washers to use as weight
A set of standard GoPro hardware

remixed_from.title: Master Ball, with magnetic clasp (Fixed Lid)

description.text:
The Lightning_Bolt_Yellow.stl piece will need supports, the other pieces shouldn't need supports.

You will need to print off one of each file, except the "Side_Piece_Yellow.stl", you will need 4 of those.

Glue two side pieces onto both the top and the bottom pieces and glue the lightning bolt into the top.

After assembling the lid and the bottom you can glue the button and ring to the bottom with the hinge in place as you glue the ring down. Then snap the hinge into the lid.

You will also need 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16"). Just glue them in place.

Netfabb seems to be gone so these files have not been put through a repair program. I've tested the preview from MakerWare Desktop and it seems like the pieces should print correctly but let me know if you have problems.

Tip: Print your bottom piece (dark blue piece) at a higher in fill percentage, around 40-50% and then all the other parts at 5-10%. That way it will be bottom heavy and not roll around as much.

title: Easy lead screw conversion for Makerfarm i3v

description.text:
This is a conversion kit I made for my Makerfarm i3v-12. I have been told it will fit other size V-slot Makerfarm printers (thank you porksmash). It replaces the threaded rod that ships with the Makerfarm with an 8mm lead screw. These lead screws are available from many suppliers. I have around $18 and some printing invested in the upgrade on my printer.

You will need to purchase the following to complete this project:

• 2 T8 leadscrews 2mm pitch with nuts (measure the threaded shaft length on your machine and match it)
• 2 5X8 flexible shaft couplers
• 2 688ZZ bearings or comparable bearing with an 8mm inside diameter and 16mm outside diameter.
• 2 M5X10mm bolts (I had several of these left over)
• 4 M3X10mm or longer bolts and nuts (I had these left over)

This upgrade adds stability to the printer (stability = print quality). It also brings the lead screw forward which places it in a better position to balance the X carriage.

All three of the printable parts must be printed twice. Once for the left lead screw and once for the right lead screw.

Step 1 - get ready

Print 2 copies of each of the three parts. Clean, sand, and check. Press fit bearings into leadscrew stabilizers. Attach lead screw nuts in the lift brackets with the shoulder to the side with more space. The shoulder side of the lift bracket is the bottom (downward) side as shown in the pictures. Use 2 M3 bolts and nuts in each bracket

Step 2 - brace up the X axis

Run the Z down near but not touching the work surface. Center the print surface under the X axis. Put two equal sized spacers under the X axis gently lifting the X axis off the Z nuts from the center. I used two matching boxes for this. Use something solid and stable. The nuts should pass out the bottom of the nut traps as you gently lift the X axis from the middle.

Send me a picture to include here. I already took mine apart.

Step 3 - remove the old threaded rods

The X axis should be stable and solid now. It should be connected to the Z (upright) v-slot rails and firmly resting on books, boxes, or some other form of spacers from the print surface. Unscrew the old Z-lift tabs from the top of the X-axis. Those are the wood tabs with the Z-nut traps attached to the underside that lift the X-axis up the threaded rods.

Now hold the Z-stepper motors in place and gently slip the tubing that connects the threaded shaft off of the stepper shaft. The shaft, nut, and Z-lift tab should now be lifted away and put in a safe place. Do this on both sides.

Send me pictures to include here please.

Step 4 - change out the Z motor mounts

Remove the Z motor mounts from the frame. Remove the stepper motors from the Z motor mounts. Change out the old Z motor mounts with the new extended Z motor mounts that you printed. This is where those square holes can be pretty tight. Work those holes until they fit snugly on the legs. Don't over work them. You want them tight and strong. Mount the stepper motors back in. Mount the assembly back on the frame.

Your Z axis has now been moved forward from the frame to accommodate the larger T8 leadscrew. This arrangement will also better support the cantilever of the X-carriage making your printer more stable. Loosen the lock screws on the flexible shaft couplers if necessary, and slip the 5mm hole over the shaft of the stepper. One side of the coupler is 5mm for the stepper and one side is 8mm for the leadscrew. If there is a flat on the shaft of your stepper, line one of the set screws up with it. Lift the shaft couplers slightly above the base of the stepper shaft and lock the set screws.

Send me pictures.

Step 5 - mount the lift brackets and lead screws

Mount the new lift brackets on the X-axis using the t-slot nuts and screws removed from the old lift brackets. Tighten them just enough to remove most of the slop but still allow you to slide the lift brackets side to side. The shoulder side of the leadscrew nut should be oriented under the lift plate.

Gently insert the leadscrew through the lift brackets allowing it to turn until it reaches the shaft coupler. Engage the leadscrew with the shaft coupler but do not tighten. We need to remove the leadscrew again before we finish.

Using one eye line the leadscrew up with the vertical v-slot behind it. Tap or slide the lift bracket side to side until the leadscrew appears perfectly aligned. Now very gently remove the leadscrew without allowing the lift bracket to shift. The leadscrew must be removed in order to tighten the set screws on the lift bracket. Tighten the lift bracket set screws now. Insert the leadscrew once again and verify alignment. Repeat the alignment steps until you are satisfied. Finally set the coupler set screws on the leadscrew.

You can now remove the blocks from under the X-axis.

WARNING - if you try to move your printer under power before you adjust the Z steps you can ruin your printer. At this point, your printer thinks that it is moving a little when it is moving a lot. You will fix this in the next step.

Step 6 - update your configuration

Set your Z steps to 400. Read on if you are unsure how or why to do that.

Your old threaded rods were a different size than these new cool and amazing leadscrews. Keep in mind that your printer doesn't know about the change yet! If you tell it to move, it will move based upon how many turns it took on the old threaded rods. One step in the Z direction is called a Z step. We need to tell the printer how many Z steps it takes to travel 1mm with the new leadscrews. If you installed the T8 2mm pitch leadscrews as I suggested, then your Z steps should be 400 or 800 depending on micro-step settings. Use 400 for now, and if everything prints half height change it to 800.

I am not going to give all of the instructions for how to set your Z steps here because there are too many variables. For some readers this is a piece of cake and for others an adventure. Go have your cake or adventure and then return to install the leadscrew stabilizers. I will give you a push in the right direction in case you need it. Google "Marlin set Z steps". If you have an LCD display you can set the Z steps with the panel under control/motion, but you will be twisting the little knob around for a long time. Don't forget to store your configuration or it will be lost when you power down the printer.

Step 7 - install Z stabilizers

Power up your printer and run the Z axis up near the top of the printer. You want the Z stabilizer to be in line with the Z lift bracket when the Z lift bracket is near the top of the printer. Slip Z stabilizers on the shafts with the lip of the stabilizer facing downward at the edge of the frame as in the pictures. The securing hole should align with the threaded hole in the center of the v-slot Z upright. The stabilizer securing hole is meant to be a little sloppy to allow play at this step. Secure the Z stabilizer with an M5 bolt.

Step 8 - clean up and play

You will need to re-level your printer and clean up your tools. Print a test object. If it prints half height see step 6 above.

You may want to change your Z maximum velocity and acceleration. Your printer is capable of higher values now, but Z moves are normally very slow in general. Be aware that your printer is now capable of driving the hotend into print surface and damaging both!

description.text:
Presenting Zippityboombot!, an articulated, print-in-place, zero-assembly robot figure. With 13 working joints, fresh off your build plate: 8 hinge, 2 ball & socket, and 3 axles. All you do is remove it from the plate and clean off the brim.

In motion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nOVHAzVpq0g

Printing: https://youtu.be/uH8uHMg9Ly0

The joints move freely once you loosen them up. If you want it to hold a pose, I found a small ball of museum wax in the joints does the trick.

Feel free to remix as you please, just attribute here.

Made one? Post a picture!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I recommend using a brim since the entire torso and head attach to the bed only by the bottom of the pelvis.

May be scaled up as big as your printer can go, but scaling it down might fuse the joints.

description.text:
Here is a remix of 2ROBOTGUY's Tri Fidget Spinner Toy. I took his design and added two elements: ridges on the edges for added traction and little bumps on the inside to help hold the bearings in place. I also moved the caps to print inside the spinner's empty space to try to save filament by reducing the area of the raft. This is my first object I've posted on Thingiverse.
The image actually contains parts from two different prints. I printed 4 spinners in black and 4 spinners in yellow and then swapped the bearing caps so all of the completed spinners have both yellow and black.

Printer:

JG Aurora A3

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2m

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I also use these bearings for the center: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01NAJ35KA

and these bearings for the outer ones: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBD6X4
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/XZ7ceJtF7I4" ></iframe>

I used Tinkercad and Cura.

To carve out space for the ridges in TinkerCad, I used Community Shaper Generator > Circular Array.

comments.text: quick question, why the 2 different bearings? wouldn't one type work as well??
comments.author: tozol

comments.text: I use a higher quality bearing in the middle because the cheap ones just don't spin as long. The center bearing costs about $1.70. The other ones are about $0.30 each. Since they're mostly just used for weight, I don't put the nice expensive ones in the outer spots.
comments.author: tozol

comments.text: Could you post some pictures of the area you added the grooves to? Very interested on how it helps. Spin on
comments.author: 2ROBOTGUY

comments.text: I added a close-up of the grooves. I have big hands and like to spin one-handed, and the grooves seem to make it easier to get a good spin off of them.

title: PTFE filament guide tube holder for Malyan M150, WanHao i3 Duplicator

description.text:
[Updated 11/26/2017 for slightly wider gap between prongs]

Remixed from Airmaxx23's great tube holder. I wanted one with as short as possible filament path and requiring no extra parts (no screws) to install. Installed on my Malyan M150 but should also work on the Wanhao i3 Duplicator and the Monorprice Maker Select since they have the same DNA.

Just slide the slot into the open corner of the printer's gantry and insert your tube. Done! Depending on the tolerances of your printer you may need to work the channels a bit with a nail file or sandpaper and a drill bit.

comments.text: Just wanted to say thanks! Simple design, easy to print/install, and works great. Definitely helped to eliminate some extrusion inconsistencies on my Maker Select v2.

description.header: Customisable conversion adaptor cowlings for fans of any size
description.text:
Files you will find for this thing consist of STL files of some common conversions as well as custom jobs made on request, the beta OpenSCAD file for the Customizer, an older version of the native SOLIDWORKS file and a newer version of the native Inventor file.
The OpenSCAD file is primarily for customisation. As of now it is a very simple and inefficient model but should be able to make simple conversions that are not already available.
The Solidworks and Inventor files can be used for customising with very basic constraints that work for most sensible conversions. The layout of the file should be easy to follow for anyone with basic knowledge of the required software.

Variables for use with The Customizer. When it comes to low power fans there is a degree of de-facto standardisation, however this is not formalised in any way. This Customizer should at least allow people to work quickly with non-standard fans as well as choose other variables to suit their needs better than my ready made adaptors can handle. The Customizer/OpenSCAD are very rough and unrefined and should be considered to be in early development. I am still coming to grips with the software and the language. However it should function fine when the size difference between fans is not too great. I will probably improve this as and when I get the chance. As always, once created, make sure you check the resultant STL before printing it. Everything should function fine, but you can never be too careful. If the Customizer doesn't work for you and you need something special making, let me know and I will see what I can do, time depending. The Customizer will ask you for 12 values. These are:
  • holeaccess
    This dictates how you access the smaller fan's mounting holes. The options are:
    Cowling: Small fan screws accessed through the cowling.
    External: Small fan screws accessed from outside of the adaptor.
    Flange: A simple flat plate with mounting holes for both sizes.
    Some models work best with external access, some with cowling access, some it doesn't matter for. Experimentation is the best way to find the right option. The Customizer makes the "Cowling" and "Flange" options look messy, but they are fine once created.
  • $fn
    This is the facet resolution and can safely be ignored.
  • smallsize
    This is the smaller fan's given size. (e.g. 60 mm, 80 mm)
  • largesize
    This is the larger fan's given size. (e.g. 92 mm, 120 mm)
  • smallflange
    This is the thickness of the smaller side's mounting flange.
  • largeflange
    This is the thickness of the larger side's mounting flange. This is also the thickness of the "Flange" option's flange.
  • wallthickness
    This is the thickness of the wall of the cowling. The part that joints the two mounting flanges. This size is added twice to the small and large fan size to dictate the size of the mounting flanges.
  • cowlingheight
    This is the height of the cowling between flanges. The total height of the adaptor will be this plus the two flange thicknesses. It is advisable to bear in mind the angle of the cowling when choosing a height, to ensure smooth and reliable printing and to a lesser degree, good airflow properties.
  • smallholes
    This is the spacing between the screw holes on the small fan side. (e.g. 50 mm, 72 mm)
  • largeholes
    This is the spacing between the screw holes on the large fan side. (e.g. 83 mm, 105 mm)
  • smallholesize
    This is the diameter of the mounting holes on the small side. (e.g. 3.5 mm) Standard PC case screws tend to be around 4.5 mm, so bear this in mind when choosing your screw hole size.
  • largeholesize
    This is the diameter of the mounting holes on the large side. (e.g. 4.5 mm)
    • As with the STL models, the default values for the customiser model are quite liberal and could be trimmed down if necessary. Customiser makes the "Cowling" and "Flange" options look messy, but they are fine once created.

Regarding fan sizes Some manufacturer's fans appear to have differing screw hole spacing in comparison to the majority. In those cases I have gone for the most common size among manufacturers. Because of this, it is worth checking the dimensions of your chosen converter before printing. These items are all fairly quick and dirty and you should check and be certain they fit what you need before printing them. If something seems wrong to you or not meeting your needs, please see the contact me section below. Information on the design The primary design variables in the model are the large and small fan sizes, their respective mounting hole spacing and their respective screw hole sizes. Additionally there are cowling and flange thickness variables as well as overall height. All of the non-bespoke models have a certain overhang which will have to be attended to when printing. This overhang will either come from the mounting hole parts of the flanges, the counterbore on the smaller side and the smoothing around the flanges near the mounting holes. All tapers take account of the 45 degree rule of thumb. Post-processing Most of these will require some post-processing. Filing of mounting holes is almost certainly going to be required along with cleaning up of the inner surfaces to ensure smooth airflow.

30th June 2014 edit: Added dodgy 2 x 80 to 120 mm thing and 40 to 25 mm. Added some new versions of 40-30, 50-30 and 50-40. 2nd July 2014 edit: Added quick CFD of the normal adaptor flow and the 2x80 adaptor. Clearly showing the inefficiency of design in the 2x80. Well, what can you expect for a quick job. 8th Feb 2015 edit: Added 25 mm to 30 mm. Very quick and dirty. I've been really busy with work recently so can't spend too much time on this at the moment. Screwing will be difficult, perhaps cable ties or wire wrap or string will do the job, at least temporarily. 21st May 2015 edit: Added 140 and 180 to 120 mm. 7th March 2016 edit: Added new 92 to 50 mm adaptors with corrected hole sizes on the 50 mm side. There are 2 versions, one with 40 mm spacing between hole centres for the 50 mm side and one with 42 mm spacing. This discrepancy comes about because of differences in datasheets from different manufacturers. So, before printing please be sure to check your dimensions. 18th March 2016 edit: Updated 60 to 30. Small side hole spacing was marginally too large. 6th August 2016 edit: Added a requested 92-120 mm with thicker construction, square flanges and 20 mm high. 3rd January 2017 edit: Updated 50-30 mm to account for hole spacing on the small side. Updated three other files with small geometry alterations. Added 90 degree bend converting from 60 to 40 mm. 6th January 2017 edit: Added two requested 140 conversions. 12th March 2017 edit: Added 80 mm to 40 mm offset adaptor by request. Very quick and not going to be very flow efficient, but will do the job to a certain extent. 11th April 2017 edit: Added 140 mm to 120 mm with offset adaptor by request. Check sizes and spacing before printing please. 12th April 2017 edit: Added a very simple OpenSCAD version. It has no refinement and will only be able to do models when there size difference is not too large. I may work on it more in the future. I just want to test out some features and the software. 26th May 2017 edit: Updated the OpenSCAD with the "Flange" option as I'd have a couple of requests for something similar. Only use this one if size is really limited, the flow will be very inefficient.

Please feel free to contact me for alterations or custom jobs. Bear in mind I am usually busy with other things and only work on this item when I get the spare time.
If you have something very specialised and specific in mind please give me as much detail as possible in your request.

description.text:
Rail Cars for the Thomas trackmaster sets. Would probably also work with Brio if you used a different connector.
I started with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:358779 and
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620364
and heavily modified it. I had 3 goals in mind.

  1. I wanted to be able to "snap" this together as much as possible straight off the printer without using any glue.
  2. I wanted to avoid supports as much as possible, the only thing you should need it for is the roof of the "box car"

  3. I wanted the set to be modular so you could print one of the Rail carriage bases and then have the different bodies fit onto it. I also designed it this way in the hopes that others would create more cars to fit the carriage. You should be able to take the "flat car" and scale many of the other designs on thingiverse to fit onto it.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed at 210 / 55 using Hatchbox black PLA on a 220x220 bed with .8mm sides and top.  Note that CURA will automatically scale down the model so you need to return it to 100% and adjust it so that is fits perfectly with a 2mm skirt.  My priming skirt actually went over the corner of the print bed by about a mm but the actual print was solid and just inside the edge of the plate.  I printed at 25% fill and I think that was plenty.

description.text:
Since the Tronxy is a different size then the Anet none of the Anet specific braces I found would fit my machine. This one is exactly 266mm from horizontal connecting edge to horizontal connecting edge, not counting the side supports. It's designed to be a friction fit between the upper and lower horizontal panels behind the lead screws and guides which on my machine were 265.87mm apart. It must be tapped in from the side gently and loosening the screws on that side will help a bit. The left side brace requires removal of the X axis stepper to fit in place. Make sure you check the inside of the connecting surfaces for any blobs as they would affect the fit. I'm sure the fit may need to be tuned a bit depending on your printers actual size and capability but minor tweaks should be possible without to much effort. The parts of the braces that push against the vertical supports are on the back side of the braces so they are hidden from view.
Engineering note: Technically any friction fit piece will gradually loosen if exposed to enough vibration but I think this one is pretty solid since it is squeezed against three different surfaces on each end. If your vertical pieces have holes in them you can run a few small zip ties through the holes and around the brace to put some additional tension on it and ensure it has no where to go but its plenty tight as is

Printer:

Tronxy P802ma

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

25% Tetrahedral

Notes:

Printed at 210 / 55 using Hatchbox black PLA on a 220x220 bed with .8mm sides and top. Note that CURA will automatically scale down the model so you need to return it to 100% and adjust it so that is fits perfectly with a 2mm skirt. My priming skirt actually went over the corner of the print bed by about a mm but the actual print was solid and just inside the edge of the plate. I printed at 25% fill and I think that was plenty.

comments.text: To print it on the bed of a TronXY P802MA rotate the object with these settings on Slic3r Y:90 Z:45.  Be sure your x and y offsets are properly calibrated.  I'd have a small brim and no skirt for that design

Minimalist, low-profile seedling tray markers. Sign is originally 1/16" thick, approx. 1" wide by 1/4" high, stick is 1 1/4" tall for high or low staking. STL files single or 10 grouping with easy to cut connection tabs to ensure all signs stick to bed until finished printing.

This is a z axis assembly I use in a 3d printer of my own design it is called the VectaPrint Odessy. The build volume in my machine is 2 cubic feet. it has a glass-surfaced heated-bed. title: Fully enclosed nickel weighted fidget spinner

description.text:
This spinner is a little special because instead of just using more bearings for the weight, it fully encloses US nickels. Part way through printing, you have to pause the print, place the nickels in, and then resume the print. Then it will bridge over the nickels and fully enclose them. Bridging can be fairly inconsistent, but adding hairspray to the top nickel should help it stick better. Your exact point you should put the nickels in will vary based on print settings like infill or whether you want a raft or not, but you should be able to figure it out by checking your print preview. It should be between 70-80%

There are 4 different options for the spinner itself.

Thicktriplespinner is a 3 armed spinner that uses 9 nickels, 3 on each arm.
Thickdoublespinner is a 2 armed spinner that uses 6 nickels, 3 on each arm.
Thintriplespinner is a 3 armed spinner that uses 6 nickels, 2 on each arm.
Thindoublespinner is a 2 armed spinner that uses 4 spinners, 2 on each arm.

I also made some bearing caps that I think are better than anything else I've found on thingiverse. They have a tiny lip so that they are raised above the bearing and don't rub against it, they lock together perfectly, and have a flat side so they print well.

If you want to use this concept to make your own spinners with enclosed nickels, I've found that 21.9mm diameter circles with 2mm height per nickel work pretty well. You should go more like 2.2mm height if you have space, though, because 2 is cutting it a bit short and it can interfere with the bridging sometimes.

comments.text: ????  I printed the thin triple spinner and it printed as a solid piece.  There were no voids left to put nickels into.
comments.author: AmyEkoMorgan

comments.text: Did you print without supports?
comments.author: AmyEkoMorgan

comments.text: No, I did not use supports.  I used a fill density of 100% so that it would be as dense as possible, but that shouldn't have filled in the space for the nickels.

Try with a fresh model download and bring it directly into your slicer. Slicers are able to rotate and move parts just fine on their own.
comments.author: AmyEkoMorgan

comments.text: I don't think that I used a repair tool on accident. I think it may be something about importing it into Tinkercad. I imported another spinner model that uses enclosed nickels (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2323277) that I had successfully printed without the need of turning the model on its side. When I "sliced it open" in Tinkercad, I saw that only 1 of the 2 spots were there for the nickels, which leads me to believe that perhaps the elements were not grouped into one before saving it (???) and that Tinkercad, for some reason, filled it it when importing it. (I am only guessing at this as I am new to 3D printing).

author: CarterFansler

title: Pandemic: The Cure - Travel Box (space for Experimental Meds)

description.text:
Here is a travel box for Pandemic: The Cure. We took The Cure and Splendor on our family vacation to Seattle last year, and while I had a nice 3d printed box for Splendor, we just relied on the bag for The Cure. Since then I've been trying to come up with a compact travel design for the base game and then the follow-on expansion - Experimental Meds. I tried 2 or 3 different approaches to this before finally landing on this one.

The box and inserts are big enough to comfortably hold both the base game and the expansion. Thru a strange twist of dice geometry, the space for loose dice can hold exactly 72 dice. The base game and the Experimental Meds expansion have a total of 71 dice, so you'll have an empty space. No, you aren't missing 1 die.

NOTE: The loose dice should be stacked against the short side of the box that has a small ridge running along it. This ridge is intended to catch the larger board box that sets on top of the trays and loose dice.

If you don't have the expansion, I'd recommend splitting the 7 sets of dice/meeples in the base game across the two dice trays. That should keep the box full, because each tray is shorter than the height of a die, which makes it easier to remove the dice. If there is too much of a gap on the loose dice side, you may need some kind of filler.

The "Original" dice tray has space for the board pegs and the 7 dice set.

Inserting / removing the trays is best done by using the tab in the center on the meeple side of a tray. To insert, hold the tray in the palm of your hand with the meeple side closest to your wrist, and set the dice side down at an angle against the box wall that doesn't have a ridge. Hold the tab with the other hand and lower the tab end into the box.

To remove, either use the tab to lift up the side of the tray and then slide your other hand underneath to lift it out, or use the fact that there is a space for one more die,to slip your finger under the edge and raise the tray and lift it out.

Printer:

Original Prusa I3 mk I

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

title: Smooth Ball Bearing Hinge with Airsoft Bearings

description.text:
Swing open a new door of opportunity with the new Easily Build ball bearing hinge.
Using airsoft bb's a ball bearings, this will bring smooth mechanical action to any door.

Materials:
15 Airsoft BB's
WD-40

Instructions:
Line up the holes in the hinges
Insert 5 BB's into the top, middle, and bottom hinge cavity (turning the hinge to make room)
A little WD-40 help work in the hinge.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30

Notes:

Printed on a heated glass bed with ABS glue

Support material is optional: when my printer is tuned support material is not required, when it is a little loose, it does require support material.
You know your printer best
Mechanical Tolerances When no tolerances where compensated for the parts the assembly doesn't fit together, but with a little wiggle room 6.3mm diameter rather than a tight 6mm the hinge rolls on by.
Mechanical Tolerances and 3D Printing Optimization This assembly shows how ball bearings can interlock an assembly of parts

15 Airsoft BB's
WD-40

remixed_from.title: Fan Shroud for HE280 Hot End

description.text:
This is a remix of Idea_Beans' Fan Shroud for HE280 Hot End

I made them lower profile as to clear the bed clips on my Orion.
I increased the length of the fan clips themselves in order to make it easier to pop on and off.
I also redesigned the air duct hopefully direct more air right to the business end of the nozzle.

My Print Settings
Layer Height: .3mm
Perimeters: 3
Infill: 0%
Supports: None
Raft: None
Scale: 1:1
I already ran the STL's though Netfabb

The pictures on this post are of the version right before this version. I am in the process of printing this iteration as I type. The only difference between this listing and the ones in the photos is the size of the air duct output holes.

Some Heat Gun Action

I used a heat gun to heat up the air duct portion of the shrouds and gently bent them down a little. I wanted this in the design but didn't want to have to use supports. To be honest, I am not even sure it matters.

author: Oshj44

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This design was inspired by Skalla_J's spool storage boxes, but for Hatchbox spools. The hatchbox spools are roughly the same outer diameter, but the inner diameter is different from the original design. Additionally, the hatchbox spools have four sets of holes for holding the end of the filament. This design uses those holes for the drawer hinges, so no drilling is necessary.

For the hinges, I use 6-32 threaded rod cut to approximately 67mm in length. Like Skalla_J's design, these thread into the drawers, with a small amount protruding from the top and bottom. The rod should thread somewhat securely into the drawer. I put the end of the threaded rod into the chuck of a power drill and used that to thread the rod into the drawer. The protruding rod ends fit into the existing holes around the edge of the spool.

After trying out Skalla_J's Spool Storage Boxes and finding it didn't fit my spools, I designed this from scratch in OpenSCAD. Since it's OpenSCAD, it is hopefully straightforward to adjust the dimensions for other spool sizes.

Unlike Skalla_J's design, this is only the drawer. I haven't created a mechanism to join the spools into a full storage system yet.

I've enabled the Customizer for this, here's an explanation of the customizer values:
Inner Diameter: The inner diameter of your spool
Outer Diameter: The outer diameter of your spool
Height: The interior height of the spool. The drawer will be this height.
Gauge: the thickness of the bottom & walls of the drawer
Hole Diameter: The diameter of the hole for the threaded rod. In theory, I believe #8 rods should be 4mm, and #6 rods should be about 3.5mm, although on my printer with this filament, a value of 4 here works well with 6-32 threaded rods.
Hole X: The X position of the center of the hole for the threaded rod. Since the diameter of a hatchbox spool is 200mm, with the spool centered on the origin, the location of the outer wall of the drawer would be 100. The hole is inset 4mm from the outer edge, so 100 - 4 gives a value of 96 here.
Hole Y: The Y position of the center of the hole for the threaded rod. This is how many mm from the edge of the drawer the hole should be inset.
Post Location: probably shouldn't be touched. This is the x/y/z location of the cylinder of the post, which should be adjusted with the hole x/y and gauge values rather than modified here.
$fn: This is openscad's idea of how smooth rounded edges should be. Higher values = more round, lower values = more blocky. There's probably no need to modify this here.

Update Feb. 25 2017:
By using longer threaded rods, you can stack spools into a tower configuration. Just thread the rods down the entire length of the tower. I've uploaded a picture of a 6 spool tower made this way.
When threading the rods through the stack of spools, I recommend using a spacer (I just used a length of 1.75mm filament) between the spools to prevent them from binding together and making the tower lopsided. After the rod has been threaded through the spools, the spacer can be removed.

Update Mar. 30 2017:
I've uploaded a _with_pegs version of the stl file. Instead of using a screw or threaded rod to attach the drawer to the spool, the drawer has pegs that should fit into the holes in the spool. It is much more difficult to print, but was added by request.

Also, by combining the drawers with thing:1677024, a tower could be built with half the number of spools.

Update Oct. 3 2017:
Uploaded hatchbox_box_thinner.stl which has slightly thinner side walls and base, and a more rounded appearance ($fn increased in the openscad file).
Check out remix thing:2556068 for a turntable base, and thing:2229936 for a set of handles and a way to screw multiple spools together. The handles and the turntable can even be used together!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

0.2

Doesn't Matter

comments.text: Thanks. If the auto-level grid isn't in the middle of my bed, how do I correct that? Also how do I configure my printer so that X=0 Y=0 is where I want it to be on the actual print surface. At the moment that spot is X=20 Y=10.
comments.author: CROSSJ0IN

comments.text: The printer head knows where it is once it finds the endstops. the code above tells it where those endstops are relative to the bed. the "X MIN POS -30" is telling the machine that the endstop is at -30, so x=0 is 30 in the other direction. Same goes for the other end stops. After you do the G28, you could try sending G1 X0 and see if X0 is the edge of the bed. If it doesn't then you may need to adjust X MIN POS by that difference. Hope that makes sense.

author: lfried

description.text:
This is a 3 winged version of my Minimal In-Line Fidget Spinner. It uses the common 608 skateboard bearings. The three outer bearings just snap into place but make sure you support the arm it's on while fitting. The middle one also clips into place. It might be a little bit fiddly but this is necessary for it to be a firm fit.

I have also included a central peg and caps. These work but I plan on improving them when I have time. I've noticed that there are very small differences in the inner diameter of the bearings so some require more force to fit than others depending on where you buy your bearings.

The idea behind this design is to be minimal in the mateiral required and to be able to print, easily pop in the bearings and start fidgeting.

Depending on your slicing software, you may have some slight stringing to tidy up on the inner edges of the outer pegs.

Snap the three outer bearings in place. If you have shielded bearings like the ones pictured, you will want to make a small modification to the middle one: Remove the shields, clean the bearing thoroughly and then lube with PTFE spray or similar. There are plenty of online tutorials of how to do this.

Redesigned version of my previous D-LI90 USB charger. Output should be enough to charge a smart phone but I wouldn't recommend trying to charge a tablet with it. Uses the charging circuit http://www.ebay.com/itm/271176654695?ssPageName=STRK:MEWAX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1423.l2649 with the terminal block removed. This one is cheaper and easier to assemble than the previous version, but also charges slower. Requires support material to print. The support material may be difficult to remove.

I used solid copper wire from an ethernet cable for the contacts, you may need to clear out the holes for the contacts with a sewing needle.
Sizing of the bottom cover may need to be tweaked to get a good fit. I'd recommend gluing it in. Alternatively, you can use Suguru to fill in the base instead.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I made a lot of Kongotronics as gifts, and the most recent is for a younger kiddo -- I was afraid she would break off the hands, so this file is the complete arm, wrist and pincers all meshed together. Obviously the hands don't move or grip, but it prints fine, and these are tough all together.  As an FYI I still clipped the shoulder mount and fastened it to the body with a woodscrew/washer so the clock is much more a toy than an appliance. Thanks to kongorilla as his meshes are superb!

original ones broke
so i made this ones...
pronned to sliding on smooth surface :)

pipe dimensions 57ID 60OD in mm.

I have lots of 1/4" screwdriver bits and adapters and sometimes I need a short handler for some works. I have tried some of the designs out there but I found some problems. Some of them are too little for my hands and the grip doesn't feel great. Some others can handle a little magnet hot-embedded that ends up popping out of the whole thing. So I started my own handle with magnets actually embedded inside (that don't pop out). This handle is a bit greater that some out there (contained in a 50x30mm cylinder) and has inside two 10x5mm rare earth neodymium magnets, one for retaining the bit and another one in the back for attaching the handle to a metal surface or even to catch ferromagnetic screws. The cool thing is that you can also use it as a fridge magnet ;-)

There are two models, a fixed one and a repairable one. The short handle is the repairable one. See 'updates' section below for more info.

You will need two of this magnets (you can grab 10pcs out there for a couple bucks) and some 3D printing skills, as you will have to pause printing TWO times to insert the magnets in mid-print to allow the printer to enclose the magnets inside the handle (can't supply instructions here for every slicer). Magnets are fragile and oxidizable, that is the reason why they are totally enclosed inside the handle to protect them, and also the reason to be 10x5mm powerful magnets to compensate the extra distance of atraction from the metallic parts.

Part prints with baseplate support only, don't use normal support as you won't be able to insert the magnets. Don't print the handle without at least the bit magnet as it behaves as an structural part. ABS recommended. At least 40% infill, 3mm shells and 0.2mm layers. Always be careful when working with this brave little magnets 'cause they are strong and can easily pinch your fingers. Don't let the kids play with them, these are not toys and extremely dangerous for little kids. So keep them out of reach of children and irresponsible people. Don't let them play with them unless enclosed in the handle.

Enjoy !

HINT: For those of you that usually buy at DX, I bought my magnets from there, SKU:388437 or SKU:374922 or similar. Not sure about the convenience of giving real links here.

UPDATE (21-MAR-2017): Redesigned the short handle to be repairable. Now the handle (the most expensive part due to the magnets) has a hexagonal hole to insert the little part that holds the bit. If this part (that has no magnet) becomes broken due to stress you just have to print it in minutes extract the damaged one and insert the new one, or just print a cople more just in case. Handle rebuilt! I have also included a hole to ease this little part extraction. Insert it with the hole in the right position. Why my need for this? well, I have strong hands... And may be a separate/interchangeable bit holder allows for different kind of bits without reprinting the whole handler and buying some more magnets... Easy part to design. I'll include some new bit parts if you ask for them with the exact specs. I have also enhanced the handle's grip decreasing the teeth number. This way you can also print the handle and the bit part in different materials. It seems to me a good idea for a plastic design. This way you can also put a separate fixed bit part with a color code for each of your favourite bits!!! I'll post pics in a couple days if I have the time.

UPDATE (20-MAR-2017): Added a new model for 10x10x5mm square magnets. I ended up with all my stock of cylindrical magnets :-) As these new magnets I bought seem to be milder, I made the design 10mm shorter to decrease overall weight, now handle's height is 40mm.

UPDATE (17-FEB-2017): Refined model for a better print and enhanced tolerances. It works straight of the bed right now, No post print work required (unless support removal). Pics of a transparent PLA print added. Maybe I design a shorter model, anyway enough and easy grip for me.
